citations.narrative:
The disposition record for one wolf-hybrid dog is still incomplete and missing required information on the official APHIS
7006 form. Failure to maintain completed animal records hinders accurate tracking, identification, and tracing of animals
upon their removal from the current facility. Each dealer and exhibitor shall use Record of Acquisition and Dogs and Cats
on Hand (APHIS Form 7005) and Record of Disposition of Dogs and Cats (APHIS Form 7006) forms to make, keep, and
maintain required information concerning each dog, unless a variance is granted by APHIS.

The facility has yet to fully complete the acquisition record for one bobcat. Acquisition and disposition records, including
offspring born at the facility, are necessary to accurately track and identify animals being used in regulated activities, as
well as aid in the detection of movement of animals upon relocation to a new site.
The facility shall make, keep and maintain records that fully and correctly include all the required acquisition and
disposition information, including: the name and address of the person from whom the animals were acquired, the USDA
license number of the person if licensed or the vehicle license number and state and driver’s license number and state if
not licensed, the name and address of the person to whom an animal was given/sold, the date of acquisition or
disposition, the species of animal and the number of animals involved.

The facility has not maintained records for one wolf-hybrid dog that was euthanized within the past year. The licensee
stated the records were erroneously thrown away. Failure to maintain the required recordkeeping information for the
required amount of time can inhibit accurate identification and tracking of animals. The facility must make, keep, and
maintain all records or forms required by this subpart for a period of 1 year after an animal is euthanized or disposed of
and for any period in excess of one year as necessary to comply with any applicable Federal, State, or local law.
To be corrected by May 11, 2023.

Upon arrival to the facility on April 22nd , the licensee found oneWhite-Tail deer deceased in its enclosure. The deer had
sustained bite marks and wounds, but the primary enclosure was still intact. The licensee stated they observed dog paw
prints outside the enclosure, as well as a pack of stray dogs identified on the surveillance cameras the following night.
The licensee suspected the same dogs were responsible for the deer attack. While the dogs did not enter the enclosure,
they were still able to harm the deer through the primary enclosure fencing.
Animals housed in outdoor enclosures are more vulnerable to harm from surrounding predatory animals and further injury
when enclosures fail to appropriately protect the animals. The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally
sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.
To be corrected by May 31, 2023.

Upon arrival to the facility on April 22nd , the licensee found one bobcat injured within its primary enclosure. The licensee
attributed the bobcat’s injury to a pack of dogs that were observed on the facility’s surveillance cameras. They also found
evidence of chewed and torn areas on one side of the perimeter fence.
During today’s inspection, the bottom edge of the perimeter fence encompassing the bobcat enclosure was lifted off the
ground. The gap between the ground and the raised fence line measured 4.25 inches.
Having a perimeter fence in place protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from
going through it or under it, permitting contact with the animals in the facility. Additionally, it serves as a secondary
containment system for the animals in the facility.
The perimeter fence must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact
between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence. Animals including, but not
limited to, bobcats housed in outdoor facilities require a 6-foot-tall perimeter fence around their enclosure and must be at
least 3-feet away from any enclosures or buildings, unless written approval by the Administrator has been obtained.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
